title: World Cup permutations: Scotland facing early exit if Japan clash is called off
text:
With the news that two World Cup pool matches have been called off, and another under review, there is some confusion over who will finish where.

England will no longer play France, while New Zealand's clash with Italy is also off - and Scotland could yet be stung by Super Typhoon Hagibis, too.

Here, Sportsmail goes through the pool by pool permutations, to clarify who is set to finish where, and who is likely to be heading home early...

POOL A

If Japan v Scotland is cancelled, Scotland will be out unless Ireland fail to register any points against Samoa.

Japan would top the Pool on head-to-head record if their match is cancelled - ahead of Ireland - meaning the Irish would play the All Blacks, and Japan South Africa in the quarter-finals.

The only way Scotland can qualify is if the Japan match is played and they win, or if Ireland lose to Samoa and they pick up two match points or more.

Matches left: Japan v Samoa - Sunday, Yokohama; Ireland v Samoa - Saturday, Fukuoka

Scotland are likely to crash out of the tournament if their match against Japan is called off

POOL B

With the cancellation of New Zealand v Italy the All Blacks top the Pool, and Italy are out.

South Africa go through as second seeds - but do not yet know who they will face as the top seeds in Pool A.

Matches left: Namibia v Canada - Sunday, Kamaishi.

New Zealand top their pool following the cancellation of their Pool B match against Italy

POOL C

England and France finish top and second respectively after their match was cancelled.

That means England are almost certain to face Australia, and France-Wales in Oita in the quarter-finals.

Matches left: Tonga v USA - Sunday, Hanazono.

England trained hard on Wednesday but will now not play until October 19 in quarter-finals

POOL D

Wales need only to avoid defeat against Uruguay to finish top of the Pool, and set up a quarter-final against France. They could go through as - technically - the only side with a perfect record in the tournament.

Australia are already through, and will play England unless Uruguay stun Wales.

Matches left: Australia v Georgia - Friday, Shizuoka; Wales v Uruguay - Sunday, Kumamoto.
